column4: This: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/help/create-a-usb-stick-on-windows
I used "Universal USB Installer", from pendrivelinux.com
Gah.

should I select Ubuntu 12.04 for "ubuntu-12.04-desktop-i386.iso"
Honestly this seems to be exactly the same as the last one.
It's not even in good English.
I mean.... "cow"?
I checked the download.
It's cherry.
So what is the problem?  (Sorry but I'm a latecomer to the issue.)
I'm attempting to use a linux USB stick to check whether a problem on my machine is hardware or OS (usually it runs win7)
Do you have a problem booting the media? Ok, I see, check the BIOS settings.

If you have verified the ISO, then you have two more issues, 1) Properly burning the ISO image to the USB device.  & 2) Configuring the BIOS settings to the point that the PC will actually boot a USB device, (and sometimes that takes some doing...).
oh that I can do.
Ok, if you properly solve those other two problems, you will be successful.
Well, I used the thing that was recommended on ubuntu.com to build the USB stick. But again, this is linux. Don't expect too much...
On the contrary, expect a lot.
That may be the problem, if you downloaded a compressed image....
I let the installer tool download the image.
Usually that is not the case, you just end up with an ISO image, (not a compressed ISO).

I've not done it on MS Windows, only on Linux so I'm not really familiar with the process for doing it on a MS Windows machine, but I'm pretty sure the instructions are correct, they are tried and proven.
well, clearly not.
You might try another USB stic,
The BIOS is set to disallow it.
well, that too, but windows is internally set up such that the installer will not let you install it to USB devices.
ThinkT510 is correct, you don't need to unplug devices, you only need to look at BIOS settings for proper choices.
This is work data on big RAIDs. The last thing I need is some linux daemon deciding they all need formatting.
This is not a MS Windows issue.
They will not all be formatted unless you select an option to do it.
That's ok, USB installs work just fine. In fact, I prefer USB install.
No, it works fine, you just have an issue or two to work out.
You'll get it if you try.
xchat *should* be in the repositories.
Did you select wrong time zone?
tzselect
Win7, yea, slightly scary
WHy wouldn't it?
if you have the partition mounted, it's mounted.  That's it.
mount
no such.
If you issue command "mount"  it will tell you where evertying is mounted.
df  will also tell you pretty much same
sudo fdisk -l
What?  mounted boot device as ____?
well, Windows mounts the boot device as c: (invariably); I was wondering where my 4GB flash key was mounted. But it sort of isn't, this being linux.
It all depends on what mount points you set up in the /etc/fstab file.  (Unless it's a USB device that you prefer to mount and umount on the fly).
du
You mean /boot/
You can place it on a separate partition if you choose to.
Yes, anything you put on a mount point goes on the disk it is mounted on. yes
Wait, I don't think I'm understanding your questions?  Are you planning a Linux install?  ... or are you trying to customize an existing one?
What is mounted on /cdrom ?
/dev/sdb1
sdb1 is the first partition on the second drive
sda1 is the first partition on the first drive
Maybe because it's dissabled?
(turned off)
What do you need blue tooth for at this point?
I see.
Well, I use wifi
Why wouldn't it?
well, you know.
Yea, I do know  :):):):)
Well, it might work after full install.
that's a bit fail.
Please disreguard dist-upgrade
Why not?
I think you are confused
By all means, use apt
Sorry, but you have been mislead about apt
You are on a live USB device, installing applications is for after the install.
What does BT mean?
You should do an install, see if it works then. Ok?
Just resize the partition(s) to make room for the Ubuntu install.
The installer will do it for you.
sure, works fine.
But if you have critical files and are worried, do a backup of them first.
Skype works fine
Blocking?
Bluetooth works.
Ok, I'm wrong. It doesnt' work.  You better go back to MS Windows.
ix6550 ? is that right?
yes.

Sure

Any configurations you do now are pointless.
Well, then don't install anything.  No one is forcing you to do anything.
What?
You are not making any sense
You are nonsensical
If you do a linux install first, you can discover things that don't work very well, but right now, you are just quibling over stuff that is mostly not relevant.
Great linux attitude! Doesn't work? Obviously not relevant then!
That is not what I said.
The USB drive that you are suing is *not* a full install.  It is *not* fully functional.  DO you undertand?
Again:  The LiveUSB you have booted to is *not* a full install and so there are some limitations.
